thread.title: Longest chain of volcanoes in the world discovered off Australia’s East CoastTravelandtourworld.com
thread.title_full: Longest chain of volcanoes in the world discovered off Australia’s East CoastTravelandtourworld.com

author: travelandtourworld.com
title: Longest chain of volcanoes in the world discovered off Australia’s East CoastTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Longest chain of volcanoes in the world discovered off Australia’s East Coast Published on : Tuesday, September 15, 2015
The longest chain of volcanoes in the world has been discovered by Australian researchers which runs along the east coast of the island continent.
It is an extinct volcano chain which stretches more than 2,000 km from south Victoria to north Queensland.
Giving details about the volcano, the study’s lead author Dr Rhodri Davies of the Australian National University said ‘the volcanic chain was created over the past 33 million years, as Australia moved north-northeast over a mantle plume hotspot which is now believed to be located in Bass Strait.’
The track has been named the Cosgrove hotspot track after one of the extinct Victorian volcanoes in the chain. The track is nearly three times as long as the famous Yellowstone hotspot tracks on the North American continent.
A volcanic chain occurs following persistent movement of a tectonic plate over these hotspots.
Australia has three volcanic chains which run along the eastern coast, but this new discovery is the most westerly.
Australia has only two active volcanoes, both off the mainland, located around 4,000 km south west of Perth, on Heard Island and McDonald Islands.
